record.attribute:
We are pleased to announce the release of a beta version of TriTrypDB. We expect TriTrypDB to remain in beta for 2-3 weeks to allow us to iron out any issues while at the same time providing you with access to the site and its tools. If you find any problems or want different functionality, please click the contact us link and let us know so we can improve the site!

‣This release includes:

    •Sequenced and annotated genomes from T. brucei, T. cruzi, L. major, L. infantum and L. braziliensis.
    •Expressed Sequence tag (EST) evidence from dbEST.
    •Proteomics evidence from multiple sources including pre-publication. These include mass evidence from T. cruzi, T. brucei and L. infantum.
    •Assembly of the T. cruzi scaffolds into chromosomes and separation into Esmeraldo and non-Esmeraldo haplotypes.
    •Synteny between the five TriTryp species.

‣The data included in TriTrypDB can be queried in many ways. For example, genes can be identified by:

    •Annotated name and/or GeneID.
    •Various features of the gene or its product.
    •Protein motifs or BLAST similarity.
    •Transcriptional or translational state (based on experimental data available).
    •Predicted putative function (GO terms and EC numbers).
    •Phenotypic profile.
    •Evolutionary profile.
Kinetoplastid Molecular Cell Biology Meeting III
The 3rd kinetoplastid molecular cell biology meeting will be held from April 26-29th, 2009 in Woods Hole, Massachusetts, USA.
The 4th World Congress on Leishmaniasis will be held from February 3rd -7th, 2009 in Lucknow, India. For more information click here.
EuPathDB to take on the kinetoplastida

We are pleased to report an award from the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in support of a TriTrypDB component of the EuPathDB family of databases, encompassing Leishmania species, Trypanosoma brucei, and Trypanosoma cruzi. A coordinated award from the Wellcome Trust will permit enhanced annotation of kinetoplastid parasites. These projects represent a collaborative effort between the GeneDB team (at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute), colleagues at the Seattle Biomedical Research Institute, and the EuPathDB team -- an NIAID-supported Bioinformatics Resource Center. Look for the first release of TriTrypDB in Jan 2009!
